awd_titl_txt: The Role of Microstructure on Crack Growth in Carburized Steels
awd_abstract_narration:
Carburization is used extensively in the transportation and heavy equipment industries to harden the surfaces of steel parts such as gears and bearings.  The process results in a gradient of residual stress in the part that provides enhanced resistance to wear and damage.  Understanding the underlying phenomena that control this enhanced resistance can lead to new technologies for carburized steel parts. This award supports fundamental scientific research to uncover the mechanisms that link processing and structure to properties and performance in these materials. The new knowledge will allow the development of heat treatment strategies to refine the surface structure produced through carburization to improve performance, and to build models to predict materials performance based on processing and surface structure.   This new knowledge has numerous applications including gear boxes, which see higher loads as vehicle lightweighting improves. Student trainees will engage in valuable educational opportunities through participation in this research.

The objectives of this work are to characterize the interaction of fatigue cracks with carburized steel microstructures that contain combinations of retained austenite and plate martensite, particularly focusing on processing strategies to refine the microstructure, and to utilize the observations to inform physically-based fatigue life prediction models in these complex microstructures. The work will be accomplished by designing variations in carburizing processing routes, including novel heat treatment processes intended to refine the carburized steel microstructure.  Then, fatigue crack growth studies will be performed with in-situ and interrupted test analysis of the crack interaction with the microstructure.  Multi-scale characterization will be utilized to quantify microstructural evolution in the vicinity of the fatigue crack, particularly with respect to retained austenite stability against transformation and microscale residual stresses present due to the transformation.  Finally, the fatigue crack growth data and characterization will inform models that predict the influence of microstructure on fatigue crack growth rates based on the effective driving force for crack growth.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we investigated the fatigue resistance of microstructures present in applications such as carburized gear steels and bearings. These microstructures contain multiple phases, the size and fraction of which can be controlled through variations in thermal processing. Furthermore, they contain retained austenite, which is a critical microconstituent that has been utilized to improve strength and ductility combinations in applications such as advanced high strength steels for automotive structures. However, relatively little work has been performed to examine its influence on relevant properties in carburized steel microstructures, especially fatigue crack growth. This project resulted in the following primary outcomes:

 

  • Five students (2 Ph.D. student, 2 undergraduate students, and 1 high school student) were involved in fundamental, yet industrially-relevant research with mentoring from both academic and industry perspectives. The students obtained professional development skills through their participation in the Advanced Steel Processing and Products Research Center (ASPPRC), an NSF I/UCRC that started in 1984. The graduate student also was supported by the NSF INTERN program, facilitating additional professional development experience at the Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE).
  • Milan Agnani earned his Ph.D. in Metallurgical and Materials Engineering and has accepted a post-doctoral research  position at Sandia National Laboratory.
  • The 2 undergraduate students are now pursuing graduate degree programs in materials engineering. 
  • The high school student working on this program is now pursuing at STEM degree at Carnegie Mellon University. A paper based on his work has been submitted to a journal, and minor revisions have been requested.
  • The research performed in this investigation can be used to help guide alloy and microstructure design for applications such as carburized gears and bearings, both of which are critical components for applications that promote a clean energy future, such as enhancing vehicle fuel efficiency and wind tower gearbox reliability.
  • In this study, we employed multiple processing strategies, including a novel step-quenching procedure to refine microstructures for improved fatigue resistance. We also developed methodologies to quantify the degree of microstructure refinement, which can be linked to both the prior processing and the resulting mechanical performance.
  • We identified processing routes to evaluate the role of retained austenite and strength level on fatigue crack growth resistance in microstructures comparable to those observed in carburized steels and bearings. The results revealed that characteristics of the retained austenite change the nature of the fracture process, but there are competing effects associated with the influence of processing on the other microstructural features. We utilized advanced characterization of the microstructure and fracture surface to establish linkages between microstructure and fatigue performance.
  • We developed a physically-based model to evaluate the role of retained austenite on fatigue behavior. The model revealed that fatigue resistance is highly sensitive to the amount and stability of the retained austenite. The model demonstrates that there is opportunity to tune retained austenite characteristics for enhanced fatigue resistance.
  • We collaborated with the staff at LANSCE to utilize their specialty neutron diffraction facilities to identify fundamental characteristics of the microstructure that affect mechanical performance.
  • The sponsors of the ASPPRC supported the work through industrial mentorship of the students and staff, alloy acquisition, and financial support of the staff. Additionally, results from the work were disseminated directly to this industry community through semi-annual reports and progress presentations. These reports and presentations were vital to the success of the projects as it allowed the staff to interact with ferrous metallurgy experts from industry; this interaction was also excellent exposure for the project as the industrial sponsors are one of the primary intended audiences of the work.
  • Multiple publications and presentations have originated from this work including a peer-reviewed journal paper, and peer-reviewed conference proceedings, presentations at national and international conferences including an invited talk at the Euromat conference in Sweden (2019), and reports and presentations to the sponsors of the ASPPRC.

 


Last Modified: 05/12/2022
Modified by: Kip O Findley

por.por_txt_cntn:
In this project, we investigated the fatigue resistance of microstructures present in applications such as carburized gear steels and bearings. These microstructures contain multiple phases, the size and fraction of which can be controlled through variations in thermal processing. Furthermore, they contain retained austenite, which is a critical microconstituent that has been utilized to improve strength and ductility combinations in applications such as advanced high strength steels for automotive structures. However, relatively little work has been performed to examine its influence on relevant properties in carburized steel microstructures, especially fatigue crack growth. This project resulted in the following primary outcomes:

 

Five students (2 Ph.D. student, 2 undergraduate students, and 1 high school student) were involved in fundamental, yet industrially-relevant research with mentoring from both academic and industry perspectives. The students obtained professional development skills through their participation in the Advanced Steel Processing and Products Research Center (ASPPRC), an NSF I/UCRC that started in 1984. The graduate student also was supported by the NSF INTERN program, facilitating additional professional development experience at the Los Alamos Neutron Science Center (LANSCE). 
Milan Agnani earned his Ph.D. in Metallurgical and Materials Engineering and has accepted a post-doctoral research  position at Sandia National Laboratory.
The 2 undergraduate students are now pursuing graduate degree programs in materials engineering. 
The high school student working on this program is now pursuing at STEM degree at Carnegie Mellon University. A paper based on his work has been submitted to a journal, and minor revisions have been requested.
The research performed in this investigation can be used to help guide alloy and microstructure design for applications such as carburized gears and bearings, both of which are critical components for applications that promote a clean energy future, such as enhancing vehicle fuel efficiency and wind tower gearbox reliability. 
In this study, we employed multiple processing strategies, including a novel step-quenching procedure to refine microstructures for improved fatigue resistance. We also developed methodologies to quantify the degree of microstructure refinement, which can be linked to both the prior processing and the resulting mechanical performance.
We identified processing routes to evaluate the role of retained austenite and strength level on fatigue crack growth resistance in microstructures comparable to those observed in carburized steels and bearings. The results revealed that characteristics of the retained austenite change the nature of the fracture process, but there are competing effects associated with the influence of processing on the other microstructural features. We utilized advanced characterization of the microstructure and fracture surface to establish linkages between microstructure and fatigue performance. 
We developed a physically-based model to evaluate the role of retained austenite on fatigue behavior. The model revealed that fatigue resistance is highly sensitive to the amount and stability of the retained austenite. The model demonstrates that there is opportunity to tune retained austenite characteristics for enhanced fatigue resistance.
We collaborated with the staff at LANSCE to utilize their specialty neutron diffraction facilities to identify fundamental characteristics of the microstructure that affect mechanical performance.
The sponsors of the ASPPRC supported the work through industrial mentorship of the students and staff, alloy acquisition, and financial support of the staff. Additionally, results from the work were disseminated directly to this industry community through semi-annual reports and progress presentations. These reports and presentations were vital to the success of the projects as it allowed the staff to interact with ferrous metallurgy experts from industry; this interaction was also excellent exposure for the project as the industrial sponsors are one of the primary intended audiences of the work.
Multiple publications and presentations have originated from this work including a peer-reviewed journal paper, and peer-reviewed conference proceedings, presentations at national and international conferences including an invited talk at the Euromat conference in Sweden (2019), and reports and presentations to the sponsors of the ASPPRC.
